titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. At the Commission Office this morning at 9. Second meeting in the case of Amos Blanchard. Saw Mr: Pitts. Called on Mr: Parsons at Mr: Pitts’s desire, and consulted him concerning John Boylston’s Will, and the claim upon Mr: Gill’s Estate— His opinion differs widely from mine— Spent the remainder of the day at my Office endeavouring to find light, both in this case, and that of G. W. M’Intire. Walk’d in the mall with Mrs: Johnson, and my wife. Evening at home.

2. At the bankrupt Office this morning; and executed an assignment of J. W. Blanchard’s personal effects to C. Paine— Called again upon Mr: Parsons, and conversed with him upon J. Boylston’s Will, & the questions resulting from it— Our opinions draw nearer together— Saw Mr: Pitts and Mr: Smith afterwards— Rest of the day at my Office— Walk’d in the Mall this Evening— Mrs: Johnson and Mrs: Adams rode out to Roxbury.— Mr: Cleland called upon me this evening— Negotiated with him a bill upon London— Mr: Smith likewise called— Mr: Sullivan has been ill, and sent for him; Mr: Gill acquiesces again in the sum which he had agreed upon with me the 12th: of last month.— So the arrangement is to be made, if it can with security.

3. Commission Office at 9. this morning. 2d: meeting for William Allis— Went with Mr: Pitts to Mr: Parsons, and to consulted him upon the papers to be drawn up in the case of Gill— But he was gone to Newbury Port— Mr: Sullivan sent a couple of mortgages, without bonds, and the mortgages so loosely drawn that I was
obliged to substitute two others in their stead.— Drew the bill of exchange on Bird Savage and Bird, for £295 Sterling, and received of Mr: Cleland $1291:50 for it— Wrote by triplicates to them— One copy, with one of the bills, sent by the brig Fox, for Liverpool— She sails to-morrow.— Deposited the money in the bank, with some addition. Wrote a letter to Mr: Stedman to send with the bonds and mortgages which Mr: Gill is to execute— We had a slight thunder shower this afternoon, preceded this day & yesterday by excessive heat—thermometer at 90— Went out to Quincy this evening; with Mr: Gardner.

4. Heard Mr: Allen of Duxbury; a young man of some genius,—in the morning against the modern philosophy— In the afternoon a comparison of human life to a pilgrimage.— Bathed this afternoon— My uncle Adams, Captain and Mrs: Beale, and Mr: and Mrs: Greenleaf pass’d the evening here— Read Plutarch’s treatise upon curiosity and some letters of Madame de Sevigne.

5. Return’d to Boston early this morning. At the Commission Office. Executed assignment of S. Gookin’s effects, to Robert Fields. Walk’d with Quincy, and talk’d about Horace’s odes.— Saw Mr: Smith, Mr: Babcock, Captain Batchelder, and Mr: Turner, upon various business.— Mr: Smith has sent off his son William, with young N. Appleton to Mr: Stedman at Lancaster, with my letter and the deeds to be executed by Mr: Gill.— Heard Mr: Emerson deliver the anniversary Oration— Dined with the Governor, and a company of about 30 gentlemen— The lieutenant Governor, Council, Judge Dana, and judge Sewall—Boston representatives, Suffolk Senators, Selectmen, Treasurer, Secretary and Attorney General, Town Clerk and Treasurer—Dr: Thacher, Mr: Emerson and Mr: Kirkland—and the Officers of the Cadet Company— Rose from table between 4 and 5.— Took a walk to see the crowd and merriment in the mall— Remainder of the day and evening at my office and at home.

6. First public meeting for Joseph Callender— Executed provisional assignment to David Green— Objections against some of the debts— Court of Common Pleas opens this day— Sale of shares in the fire and marine insurance company, and in the United States Bank— Most of the day at my Office— Evening at home. Mr: Storer, Mr: Smith and Dr: Welsh with their families spent it with us.

7. Forenoon at my Office— Afternoon at the Office of the Commissioners. Third meeting for Patrick Phillips, in whose case several questions of some magnitude have arisen— Walk’d with the Ladies in the Mall— Afterwards spent the remainder of the evening at Mr: Popkin’s with the club.

8. Executed an assignment of J. W. Blanchard’s effects to Edward Sharp, and a certificate of conformity to James Campbell— Called on Mr: Gurley and had some conversation with him— Rest of the day at my Office; walk’d with the Ladies in the mall, this Evening.

9. Attended at the Court of Common pleas; and in the afternoon at the Bankrupt Office— Third meeting for J. W. Blanchard— Signed also a certificate of conformity for Patrick Phillips— J. Gardner pass’d an hour with me at my Office— Evening at Mr: Smith’s.

10. Opened a Commission vs. Nathl: H. Richardson at 9 this morning. Forenoon at my Office— At 4 in the afternoon I took a seat in the Stage to Quincy.— It was full beyond measure— At Milton I left it, and walked on— Met my mother who was taking a ride; and went home with her.

11. Bathed this morning— Heard Mr: Whitney— Walk’d with my father over the hills— B. Beale & Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf here in the Evening. I read Plutarch’s treatise upon tranquility of mind— And more of Madame de Sevigne’s letters— With these I am very much pleased— I commence this day my 36th: year— Deposited in my father’s hands one copy of my Will.

12. Went with my father early this morning, and looked over an old house of his, to see if it can be repaired, to make it a convenient summer residence for my family— I took Susan over to her school at Mrs: Cranch’s; in Milton— Then return’d as far as Mr: Gardner’s, and came with him into Boston— He dined with us.
At 5 in the afternoon had a private meeting in the case of Nathl: H. Richardson— Adjourned it untill to-morrow morning.— Walk in the evening, alone, and afterwards with Mrs: Adams and Caroline.— Mr: Quincy called to ask me to go out with him and survey the place for a bridge— But I could not go.

13. At the Commission Office this morning— Assignment of J. W. Blanchard’s real Estate &c— The Court of Common pleas sat, and I attended it— Walk’d with Quincy in the Mall, and afterwards spent the Evening at his house—Mr: & Mrs: Otis there— I called in the forenoon, with Mrs: Adams upon Mr: and Mrs: Tilghman; who are here on a visit from Philadelphia.
14. At the Bankrupt Office, the Court of Common Pleas, and my own office, the whole day— Spent the evening with the club at Quincy’s.

15. Attended at the Court of Common-Pleas— In the forenoon tried the cause of Marshall vs. Orrok, verdict for the plaintiffs— In the afternoon, commenced the trial of another cause, Saxton & Wainwright vs Vinal—the conclusion of the cause postponed, untill to-morrow— At the Bankrupt Office— Executed an Assignment of Faxon’s personal effects. Examined books at my Office upon points of evidence; untill 8 o’clock— Evening at Mr: Otis’s (the father.)

16. Second meeting of Commissioners in the case of Bigelow & Beale— Finished the trial of Saxton & Wainwright vs Vinal, at the Court of Common Pleas— Verdict against Vinal— Signed the first certificate for J. W. Blanchard. Walk’d in the Mall with Mrs: Johnson and Mrs: Adams— The thermometer was at 114 in the sun, this afternoon— At 86 in the shade.

17. At the Bankrupt Office this morning at 9. o’clock— Afterwards at the Treasurer’s and Secretary’s Offices— In the latter I lodged the receipt of the County Treasurer for the duty on my Commission as a Justice of the Peace. At noon I went to Milton with Mr: Gardner and dined with him— His brother in Law J. Amory was there— We afterwards went over to his house— Saw his wife & her sister— Callender was there too— Walk’d over to Quincy— Mrs: Johnson, Mrs: Adams and Caroline had just arrived there before me— They came out in the afternoon.

18. Heard Mr M’Kean of Milton, upon humility in the morning, and upon zeal in the afternoon. Bathed this afternoon— Rode up to Braintree with Mrs: Adams in the Evening— Read Plutarch’s treatise upon false shame, and some letters of Madame de Sevigné— Began upon the second volume— Ease, simplicity and liveliness are the recommendations of her style— Indelicacy of thought is its greatest objection— But this is excessive

19. Rode with my father down to Germantown early this morning; to examine for a fit situation to build a house— After breakfast, return’d to Boston— Mrs: Johnson remained at Quincy— We had almost a storm of rain, all the way to Boston— At 4 this afternoon attended at the Bankrupt Office— Had a second meeting in the case of Joseph Callender— It kept us untill 8 in the evening— Called to Mr: Bourne’s Office, to attend at the taking of a deposition in the case of Pollock vs Babcock; but I could not stay.— It was postponed untill to-morrow afternoon, three o’clock— Shaw went to visit the Middlesex Canal.

20. At the bankrupt office this morning and executed an assignment— Called this forenoon to see Coll: Humphreys and his lady at Mrs: Carter’s— Saw Mr: Dallas there— In the evening we called at Mr: Quincy’s, to see Mr: and Mrs: Wolcott— Coll: Humphreys was there— Mr: Gardner was in town this afternoon— Walk’d with him— This day the new appointment of General Commissioners of Bankruptcy arrived here— None of the former Commissioners are appointed, except Mr: Dawes.

21. Attended the bankrupt Office at 9 this morning. 3d: meeting for Amos Blanchard— At the Common Pleas which sat to make up judgments— Went with Quincy to the Senate chamber, to hear the case of reference between the Commonwealth and the Town of Boston, relative to the Old State-House. Afterwards went with Quincy to the Library-room of the Historical Society— Remainder of the day at my Office— Evening at Club; at Mr. Smith’s—Mr: Wolcott was there.

22. Third meeting at the bankrupt-office, in the case of S. Gookin— Attended again at the reference respecting the old State-house.— Was at a Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University— Rest of the day at My Office— Walk’d in the Evening with Mrs: Adams and Caroline— Great warmth.

23. Executed an assignment this morning at the bankrupt Office— Attended at Mr: Bourne’s to the taking of a deposition in the case of Pollock vs Babcock— Afterwards at my office— Greater part of the afternoon at home— Weather so warm, could scarcely read at all— Walk’d in the Mall, at the close of the evening.

24. At the bankrupt Office this morning— 3d: meeting for William Allis— Had a heavy thunder-shower about noon— In the afternoon I went out to Quincy, with W. Shaw— Mr: Gardner and his little girl were with us to his house— Found Mrs: Johnson, and Miss Hannah Adams at Quincy.— T. Welsh junr: came in the Stage, soon after us.

25. Bathed at the wharf below Mr: Black’s— Heard Mr: Whitney— Occasional on the death of Mrs: Barrett— Read Plutarch’s treatise upon brotherly-love, and a few of Madame de Sevigné’s letters. Wrote to my brother.

26. Bathed again— Return’d to Boston with Mrs: Johnson, W. Shaw and T. Welsh.— At My Office the day through— Quincy there most of the afternoon; we drew up some regulations to be reported for the bridge over Neponset river— Walk’d with him afterwards in the Mall.

27. Meeting at the bankrupt office this morning at 9.— Quincy afterwards at my Office— I pass’d the day there— Evening at Mr: Storer’s; Mr: Otis (the father) Mr: Smith & Dr: Welsh with their families were there—

28. At 8 this morning, I went with a party of about seventy-five persons, at the invitation of the Selectmen, to Deer-Island— We stop’d at Castle Island, and viewed the new fortifications there— Dined on Deer Island, and returned at Night— Genl: Moultrie of South Carolina, Coll: Humphreys, Judge Bourne and Judge Smith were of the party— In the evening I attended the club at Dr: Spooner’s.

29. Went out to Quincy with Judge Wolcott and Mr: Quincy and their Ladies, Miss Morton, and Mrs: Adams— Dined at My father’s, and return’d to Boston in the evening; we came back, round by Mr: Quincy’s farm.

30. Day at my Office— Mr: Quincy and Mr: Morton were there, on the reference of a question between the Union bank and Mr: Morton, to Mr: Hall and myself— Purchased a pew in the first Church—one of fourteen newly made and now sold at Auction— Mr: Gardner at my Office in the afternoon. Walk’d with him; and afterwards in the Mall, alone.

31. At the bankrupt Office this morning— Third meeting for B. Faxon.— Mr: W. Cranch—Dr: Tufts, Mr: Townsend and Mr: Boylston were at my Office in the morning— Mr: Gardner in the afternoon.— Went out to Quincy with Mrs: Adams.

Day. Rise usually at about 6. Walk an hour in the Mall, or elsewhere— Write, on private business untill 9. Breakfast— At the Bankrupt Office or my own, from that time untill 2. Then return home to dinner. At 3. return to my Office, and read untill 7. Walk an hour, alone, or with the ladies— Remainder of the evening at home.— As a new set of Commissioners of bankruptcy have been appointed, I shall henceforth have but little of that business to do— Merely to finish the Commissions upon which the proceedings have been commenced.
